MI101.name: Understanding Media and Information
MI101.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI101.description: Critique and analysis of media including television, radio, film, handhelds, video games, social media and the Internet. Media history, effects and ethics. Technology, business and social developments affecting the media in the information society.

MI201.name: Media and Information Technologies and Industries
MI201.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI201.description: Operational principles and applications of media and information technologies and services. Technological, business, and policy developments transforming media and information industries. Local, national and global players in the media and information sector.

MI211.name: Documentary History and Theory
MI211.description: Documentary history and theory form its origins to the present.
MI211.restrictions: Open to students in the School of Journalism or in the Department of Media and Information or in the Department of Writing, Rhetoric and American Cultures or in the Documentary Studies Specialization or in the Film Studies major.

MI220.name: Methods for Understanding Users
MI220.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MI220.description: Basics of user research methods, such as interviews, surveys, content analysis, and focus groups. Methods to generate design ideas, solve design problems, and communicate the results.

MI227.name: Concept Design for Games, Film, and TV
MI227.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MI227.description: Introduction to theories and techniques for generating concept art and design for games, films, TV, and animations.
MI227.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Game Design and Development Minor or in the Fiction Filmmaking Minor.

MI230.name: Game Design
MI230.description: Analyze, critique, and design of non-digital and digital games. Overview of game industry.
MI230.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering or in the Game Design and Development Minor or in the Information and Communication Technology for Development Minor.

MI231.name: Game and Interactive Media Development
MI231.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MI231.description: Brainstorming, planning, implementing, and troubleshooting applications and interfaces for games and interactive media. Basic principles of programming for interactivity.
MI231.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Design Specialization.

MI239.name: Digital Footprints: Privacy and Online Behavior
MI239.description: Exploration of digitization and capture of personal information. Issues of privacy, anonymity, and ownership. Technologies involved in capturing personal information.
MI239.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MI241.name: Filmmaking I
MI241.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI241.description: Process of creating a film product. Basic camera operation, sound capture, the editing process and producing a final product.
MI241.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information.

MI247.name: Three-Dimensional Graphics and Design
MI247.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI247.description: Principles of 3D computer graphics applied in cinema, games, illustration, design and sculpture. Use of 3D software to create and manipulate synthetic objects, materials, lights, and cameras.
MI247.prerequisite: (CAS 116) or (STA 110 and STA 113) or (CAS 205 or CAS 206 or CAS 207)
MI247.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Game Design and Development Minor or in the Computer Science Major or in the Graphic Design Major or in the Bachelor of Fine Arts in Studio Art or in the Studio Art Major.

MI250.name: Introduction to Applied Programming
MI250.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MI250.description: Creation of software that responds to user input. Introduces variables, control structures, problem decomposition, finding and using existing libraries/APIs, producing user visible output, testing, creating documentation, and using version control.

MI291.name: Special Topics
MI291.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MI291.description: Contemporary issues in media and communication technology.
MI291.restrictions: A student may earn a maximum of 16 credits in MI 291 and MI 491.

MI301.name: Bringing Media to Market
MI301.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI301.description: Process of bringing media to market across multiple delivery platforms including broadcast, cable, satellite, Internet and mobile devices. Organization of creative industries, distribution methods, pricing and business models. Creation and repurposing of content. Practical and theoretical models of the behavior of media and information consumers.
MI301.prerequisite: (MI 201 or concurrently) or CAS 114 or BUS 190

MI302.name: Networks, Markets and Society
MI302.description: Theories and methods for understanding dynamic systems in which information and communication technology (ICT) and society evolve interdependently over time. Explores how ICTs shape human experience, and how politics, commercial interests and culture shape how ICTs are designed.

MI305.name: Media and Information Policy
MI305.description: National, international and local policies and private agreements governing traditional, new and emerging media, including radio, television, film, games, social media, mobile communications and the Internet.

MI311.name: Introduction to Documentary Production
MI311.description: Introduction to documentary production using accessible and affordable digital technology.
MI311.restrictions: Open to students in the Documentary Production Minor.

MI320.name: Reasoning with Data
MI320.description: Explore and summarize structured data using simple statistics such as means, standard deviations, contingency tables, and hypothesis tests, and use this data to evaluate arguments and draw conclusions about technology performance and human behavior.

MI327.name: Advanced Concept Design for Games, Film, and TV
MI327.description: Advanced topics in generating concept art and design for games, films, and animations.
MI327.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Game Design and Development Minor or in the Fiction Filmmaking Minor.

MI335.name: Film Directing
MI335.description: Concepts and techniques for directing in styles most associated with the art of film. Studies of innovative film directors. Skills of film directing, including script and shot breakdown. Directing actors and crew. Directing on location.
MI335.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Fiction Filmmaking Minor.

MI337.name: Compositing and Special Effects
MI337.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MI337.description: Conceptual and technical use of animation and compositing software for television, cinema, interactive media, and live performance.
MI337.prerequisite: {(CAS 112) and (CAS 111 or CAS 116)} or THR 219 or (CAS 201 and CAS 202) or (CAS 205 or CAS 206 or CAS 207)
MI337.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Department of Theatre.

MI341.name: Filmmaking II
MI341.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI341.description: Film style planning, techniques, and aesthetic principles for cinema and television production.
MI341.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Documentary Production Minor or in the Fiction Filmmaking Minor.

MI342.name: Multi Camera Production for Television
MI342.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI342.description: Conceptualizing, designing, planning, producing, directing and evaluating multi-camera video programs.
MI342.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Documentary Production Minor or in the Fiction Filmmaking Minor.

MI343.name: Audio Production
MI343.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI343.description: Basic audio production techniques. In-depth audio and radio industry analysis. Media writing.
MI343.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Documentary Production Minor or in the Fiction Filmmaking Minor.

MI344.name: Sound Design for Cinema, Television, and Games
MI344.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI344.description: Principles, technology, and techniques of sound design for media projects, including film, games, television, animation, and web.
MI344.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Documentary Production Minor or in the Fiction Filmmaking Minor.

MI347.name: Advanced Three-Dimensional Computer Animation
MI347.description: How aesthetic skill, technical competency, and engaging performance are woven together to create compelling animation using 3D computer graphics. Use of industry standard software to create, manipulate and render synthetic characters and their environments.
MI347.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Game Design and Development Specialization.

MI349.name: Web Design and Development
MI349.semester: Fall of every year, Summer of every year
MI349.description: Preproduction, design and development of web sites, services, and applications that employ primarily web browser technologies.
MI349.prerequisite: (MI 220 or MI 231 or CSE 231) or (CAS 204 and CAS 205)
MI349.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering or in the Design Specialization or in the Information and Communication Technology for Development Minor.

MI350.name: Evaluating Human-Centered Technology
MI350.description: How to form context-specific inquiry based on user needs and goals, assess fundamental usability problems, conduct lab-based summative evaluation methods, summarize their evaluation results into reports and design suggestions.

MI351.name: Producing For Cinema and Television
MI351.description: Conceptualizing, designing, planning, and developing projects for cinema and television.
MI351.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Documentary Production Minor or in the Fiction Filmmaking Minor.

MI355.name: Media and Information Research
MI355.description: Applied media and information research methods, practices, techniques and ethics. Data analytics, visualization and online research methods.

MI360.name: Media and Information Management
MI360.description: Basic principles of managing and financing media and information companies, media projects, and information applications.

MI361.name: IT Network Management and Security
MI361.description: Structure, design, and management of data networks with a focus on business settings. Examination of information technology security issues specifically in the context of data networks and new, digital media and ITs.

MI377.name: Advanced 3D Modeling
MI377.description: Learn advanced techniques in 3D modeling and texturing for games, movies, television, and motion graphics.
MI377.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information.

MI401.name: Topics in Media, Information and Society (W)
MI401.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI401.description: Cultural, technological, and design evolution of media and information. Conventional and emerging theories of media processes and effects. Critical examination of empirical research concerning social impacts of media, information technologies, and the Internet.
MI401.prerequisite: (MI 101) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

MI411.name: Collaborative Documentary Design and Production (W)
MI411.description: Design and development of documentaries in a team setting using video and audio, still photography, web design, and print media. Participation in a production cycle including idea generation, research, design, production, and distribution.
MI411.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MI411.restrictions: Open to students in the Documentary Production Minor.

MI419.name: Projection Design for Live Performance
MI419.description: Creating projection performance media through script, technology advancements, and production analysis. Practical application through digital rendering, video production and software exploration.

MI420.name: Interactive Prototyping
MI420.description: Creation of iterative and diverse prototypes of computer-based technologies that satisfy user needs. Low-fidelity prototypes that can be used for design feedback and medium-fidelity working prototypes that can be used to assess interactivity and social goals.

MI431.name: Advanced Game Development
MI431.description: Advanced concepts in planning, implementing, and troubleshooting applications and interfaces for games and interactive media.
MI431.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering or in the Game Design and Development Minor.

MI435A.name: Creating the Fiction Film I
MI435A.description: Creation of a short film, including scripting, conceptualization and planning, shooting, and rough editing.
MI435A.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Fiction Filmmaking Minor or approval of department.

MI435B.name: Creating the Fiction Film II (W)
MI435B.description: Finishing a short film, including fine editing, color correction, sound design, and foley work. Developing web promotion, marketing strategies, and distribution.
MI435B.prerequisite: (FLM 435A or approval of department) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MI435B.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Fiction Filmmaking Minor or approval of department.

MI440.name: Advanced Video Editing
MI440.description: Advanced principles, technology and techniques of video editing.
MI440.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Documentary Production Minor or in the Fiction Filmmaking Minor.

MI441.name: Advanced Lighting and Camera Techniques
MI441.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MI441.description: Advanced techniques for manipulation of light and image characteristics in film and television settings.
MI441.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Documentary Production Minor or in the Fiction Filmmaking Minor.

MI442.name: Design of Cinema and Television Projects (W)
MI442.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI442.description: Develop TV, video and film projects in a group setting. Practice a full production cycle including idea development, budgeting, pitching, teaser, trailer, production, postproduction, distribution and evaluation. Production case studies, advertising, ethics and worldwide media and job trends.
MI442.prerequisite: (MI 341) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MI442.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Documentary Production Minor or in the Fiction Filmmaking Minor.

MI443.name: Audio Industry Design and Management (W)
MI443.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI443.description: Advanced audio production specializing in multi-channel techniques. Industry focus on all aspects of the audio field.
MI443.prerequisite: (MI 343) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MI443.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the Department of Media and Information.

MI444.name: Information Technology Project Management
MI444.description: Practical training and experiences in design, testing, and launch of new information technologies and systems.
MI444.restrictions: Open to students in the Information Technology Minor.

MI445.name: Game Design and Development I
MI445.description: Design, architecture, and creation concepts related to the development of interactive digital games.
MI445.prerequisite: MI 231 or CSE 331 or CSE 335 or STA 360
MI445.restrictions: Open to students in the Game Design and Development Minor and open to graduate students in the Department of Media and Information.

MI447.name: Graphics and Animation Portfolio (W)
MI447.description: Development of a portfolio of advanced three-dimensional models, animation, concept design, and technical art to focus skills on a specific profession or industry.
MI447.prerequisite: (MI 327 or MI 347 or MI 377) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MI447.restrictions: Open to seniors or graduate students in the Department of Media and Information.

MI449.name: Advanced Web Development and Database Management
MI449.description: Learn and apply server-side web technologies and database integration with client-side web technologies, to design, development, and deploy modern web sites, services, and applications.
MI449.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering.

MI450.name: Creating Human-Centered Technology (W)
MI450.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MI450.description: Entire human-centered design process, including assessing needs, forming ideas, designing a solution, building prototypes, evaluating the effectiveness of those solutions, and iterating to improve the solutions. Creation of a portfolio piece to illustrate capabilities.
MI450.prerequisite: (MI 320 and MI 350 and MI 420 or approval of department) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MI452.name: Media Entrepreneurship and Business Strategies
MI452.description: Entrepreneurship and business strategy options, with their attendant risks and opportunities, available to media firms in an industry that is being dynamically transformed by new information and communication technologies.
MI452.prerequisite: (MI 301) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

MI455.name: Game Design and Development II
MI455.description: Advanced design, architecture, and creation concepts related to the development of real-time interaction 3D design for gaming, simulation, and immersive virtual environments.
MI455.restrictions: Open to students in the Game Design and Development Minor and open to graduate students in the Department of Media and Information.

MI462.name: Social Media and Social Computing
MI462.description: Social and technological perspectives on how people collaborate using social media and other information and communication technologies. Experience with using multiple collaboration platforms and analysis of differences between enabling technologies.
MI462.prerequisite: (MI 349 or MI 361 or approval of department) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MI462.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

MI472.name: Digital Business and Commerce
MI472.description: Technologies, business models, and organizational and social implications of electronic commerce. Strategies for designing, managing and marketing in digital commerce contexts.
MI472.prerequisite: ((MI 349 or MI 361) or approval of department) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
MI472.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

MI480.name: Information and Communication Technologies and Development
MI480.description: Role of information and communications technologies (ICT) in low income countries and in disadvantaged areas in middle and high income countries. Theories and case studies that link ICT and social, political, economic and environmental change.
MI480.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MI482.name: Building Virtual Worlds
MI482.description: Theoretical and practical approaches to the planning, design, and development of virtual worlds for games and simulations.
MI482.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Game Design and Development Minor.

MI484.name: Building Innovative Interfaces
MI484.description: Designing, implementing and evaluating new interaction devices using mobile and sensor technologies.
MI484.prerequisite: MI 231 or MI 250 or CSE 320 or CSE 331 or CSE 335
MI484.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering or in the Game Design and Development Minor.

MI488.name: Information and Communication Technology Development Project (W)
MI488.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI488.description: Challenges and opportunities of implementing an information and communication technology in a developing country or underprivileged region of the United States. Hands-on experience conducting field work on location.
MI488.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MI490.name: Independent Study
MI490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI490.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Department of Media and Information. Approval of department; application required.

MI491.name: Special Topics
MI491.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MI491.description: Contemporary issues in media and communication technology.
MI491.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the Department of Media and Information. A student may earn a maximum of 16 credits MI291 and MI491.

MI493.name: Internship
MI493.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI493.description: Supervised professional experience in a media or information institution, business or facility.
MI493.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Department of Media and Information. Approval of department; application required.

MI497.name: Game Design Studio
MI497.description: Conceptualization, design documentation, planning, prototyping, and distribution of games.
MI497.restrictions: Open to students in the Game Design and Development Specialization and open to graduate students in the Department of Media and Information.

MI498.name: Collaborative Game Design (W)
MI498.description: Design and development of comprehensive digital games in a team setting working with a client. Participation in a design cycle including specification, design, prototyping, implementation, testing, and documentation. Issues of professionalism, ethics, and communication.
MI498.prerequisite: (MI 497 or MI 482 or MI 447) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
MI498.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Media and Information or in the Game Design and Development Minor.

MI803.name: Introduction to Quantitative Research Methods
MI803.semester: Fall of every year, Summer of every year
MI803.description: Introduction to quantitative social science research methods and applied analyses for understanding research reports and developing graduate level research projects.

MI820.name: Theories of Media and Information
MI820.description: Classic and contemporary theories of communication and information with special emphases on applications to current and emerging media, and information and communication technologies viewed from a socio-technical perspective.
MI820.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of department.

MI830.name: Foundations of Serious Games
MI830.description: Rationales, principles, processes, and pedagogies for serious game design. Applications of serious game genres and simulations. Funding and distribution.
MI830.restrictions: Open to students in the Media and Information Major or in the Serious Game Design and Research Certificate or in the Educational Technology Major or in the Educational Technology Graduate Certificate or approval of department.

MI831.name: Theories of Games and Interaction Design
MI831.description: Theories of interaction in games and other mediated contexts including communication, learning, health, global and local development, and social justice to inform the design of social systems, games and other interactive media products.
MI831.restrictions: Open to students in the Media and Information Major or in the Serious Game Design and Research Certificate or in the Educational Technology Major or in the Educational Technology Graduate Certificate or approval of department.

MI839.name: Game and Film Design Studio I
MI839.description: Design principles for the creation of transmedia (games, film, websites, etc.). Design and development studio course focused on the creation of fictional storytelling projects across media projects.
MI839.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of department.

MI841.name: Understanding Users
MI841.description: Methods of user-centered research to support game, media and interaction design. Iterative cycles of user and product conceptualization.
MI841.restrictions: Open to students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or in the Media and Information Major or in the Serious Game Design and Research Certificate or in the Educational Technology Major or in the Educational Technology Graduate Certificate or approval of department.

MI844.name: Interaction Design
MI844.description: Design of user interactions in information and media systems. Prototyping and presentation tools. Example topics include information architecture, task analysis, use cases, wire frames, scenarios.
MI844.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of department.

MI845.name: Interactive Usability and Accessibility: Design and Evaluation
MI845.description: Principles and theories of usability and accessibility in interactive media, social and mobile computing, virtual environments and information appliances. Approaches to design and evaluation.
MI845.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of department.

MI846.name: Game and Film Design Studio II
MI846.description: Design principles for the creation of transmedia (games, film, websites, etc.). Design and development studio course focused on the creation of fictional storytelling projects across media projects.
MI846.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of department.

MI850.name: Media and Information Policy
MI850.description: Discusses major public and private media and information policies, including Internet governance, and their relevance and implications for businesses, professionals in the field, and users of advanced communications. Applies concepts and data from media and information studies, management, technology, law, and political science.
MI850.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of department.

MI851.name: Understanding and Managing Social Media
MI851.description: Overview of social media applications and services, social media history, social media affordances, effects on individuals, organizations, and society, and best practices for the management and study of social media.
MI851.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of department.

MI852.name: Media and Information Economics
MI852.description: Economic dynamics of the digital economy and its implications for businesses and managers. Emphasis on traditional and new media industries, including Internet-based media, mobile communications, social media, and information industries.
MI852.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of department.

MI861.name: Media and Information Technologies in Organizations
MI861.description: Applications of media and information technologies in business settings. Implications for management of information technologies derived from an examination of effects of media and information technologies from a socio-technical perspective.
MI861.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of department.

MI862.name: Managing Digital Enterprises
MI862.description: History and current status of e-commerce, e-commerce strategies and approaches, and new directions in e-commerce. Challenges of developing and marketing an online commerce site.
MI862.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of department.

MI875.name: Information and Communication Technology and Development
MI875.description: Information and communication technology in developing areas, cases studies, design and implementation, and critical evaluation of the role of ICTs in development.
MI875.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of department.

MI877.name: Global Media and Communications
MI877.description: Comparative and international perspectives on approaches to traditional and new media and their transformations by increased global connectivity. Addresses broadcasting, cable TV, satellite, fixed networks, mobile communications, and the Internet. Political economy of media, economic, institutional and content issues. Interactions and media flows among countries. International governance bodies.
MI877.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of department.

MI890.name: Independent Study
MI890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI890.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Media and Information. Approval of department; application required.

MI891.name: Special Topics in Media and Information
MI891.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MI891.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of department.

MI893.name: Media and Information Internship
MI893.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI893.description: Internships in media and information industries.
MI893.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of department.

MI898.name: Master's Project
MI898.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI898.description: Plan B individual project or poster demonstrating master's level professional competence.
MI898.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Department of Media and Information. Approval of department; application required.

MI899.name: Master's Thesis Research
MI899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI899.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Media and Information. Approval of department; application required.

MI900.name: Theory Building in Media and Information Studies
MI900.description: Concepts and issues relating explanation, scientific inquiry, theory building and applications to interdisciplinary studies in media and information.

MI912.name: Information Technology Transactional Perspectives
MI912.description: Multiple perspectives on relationships between organizations and information technology. Information processing, communications and management strategy approaches. Economic perspectives.

MI916.name: Qualitative Research Methods
MI916.description: Qualitative research in mass and specialized communication systems. Topics include documentary, bibliographic, case study and participant observation methods.
MI916.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences.

MI921.name: Theories of Media and Information
MI921.description: Overview of the relations between information theory, communication theory, and media theory, and an understanding of how these theories have evolved over time and which competing approaches coexist.
MI921.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of college.

MI960.name: Media and Technology
MI960.description: Theoretical frameworks concerning media and communication processes, and their interactions with technology. Social, organizational, critical, and economic perspectives.
MI960.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Communication Major or in the Media and Information Studies Major or approval of department.

MI975.name: Introductory Methods
MI975.description: A survey of qualitative and quantitative research design including validity and reliability, hypothesis formation, sampling, ethics, survey, experimental, ethnographic, observational and mixed methods.

MI985.name: Advanced Quantitative Analysis for Media
MI985.description: Multivariate research methods for media and information studies research.

MI990.name: Independent Study
MI990.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI990.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of college.

MI991.name: Ways of Knowing
MI991.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MI991.description: Ways humans acquire, convey, organize and shape knowledge and information, and are shaped and influenced by it. Neurological, psychological linguistic, philosophical, cultural, and logical dimensions of human knowledge.
MI991.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of college.

MI992.name: Doctoral Seminar
MI992.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MI992.description: Topics on theoretical and research issues in communication and mass media.
MI992.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of college.

MI993.name: Research Practicum in Information and Media
MI993.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MI993.description: Directed research collaboration with a faculty member or a team of students/faculty.
MI993.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of college.
